title: Red Jade
text:
The Red Jade was <a href="Ericsson">Ericsson</a>'s unreleased handheld console, intended to compete with the <a href="Game%20Boy%20Advance">Game Boy Advance</a>. 
History.
Development.
<a href="Fredrik%20Liljegren">Fredrik Liljegren</a> founded Red Jade as a startup company in February 2000. The startup included other notable developers such as <a href="Robert%20J.%20Mical">Robert J. Mical</a>. Originally the developing team for the Red Jade approached <a href="Sony">Sony</a> and <a href="Sega">Sega</a> as potential partners but both declined. Ericsson decided to invest US$10 million in the Red Jade, It was to be released by Christmas season 2002 and would have retailed for $150.
Cancellation.
When overall sales plummeted, Ericsson cancelled the Red Jade before production in April 2001 and cut 22,000 employees to help minimize losses. The collapse of the <a href="Dot-com%20bubble">Dot-com bubble</a> left the startup in a position where it was unable to find other investors to continue development. The number of existing <a href="prototype">prototype</a> units is unclear along with possibility of games made for them. <a href="Quake%20III%20Arena">Quake III Arena</a> was said to have received a port. Ericsson's mobile phone division later divested into joint venture with <a href="Sony">Sony</a> and rebranded as Sony Ericsson, until Sony acquired Ericsson's share and became <a href="Sony%20Mobile%20Communications">Sony Mobile Communications</a>. In 2006 Red Jade as a company would be restarted by Liliegreen to operate as a game development studio.
Specifications.
The Red Jade which was supposed to have PDA functions, wireless connectability, <a href="DivX">DivX</a> movies, cell phone capabilities, a <a href="GPS">GPS</a> server, <a href="MP3">MP3</a> audio playback, a web browser, the ability to download games from the website, game sharing utilizing <a href="Bluetooth">Bluetooth</a> technology, and graphics equivalent to the <a href="PlayStation">PlayStation</a> or <a href="Nintendo%2064">Nintendo 64</a>.
